title: 110_hr3273
content: The Act is titled the "United States-China Market Engagement and Export Promotion Act" and includes provisions for grants to states, establishing China market advocate positions, assisting small- and medium-sized businesses with trade missions to China, and consolidating fees for Gold Key matching services. The Act includes provisions for trade outreach at the Small Business Administration and grants for Chinese business education programs. Additionally, grants are provided to states to establish offices promoting exports to China. The Secretary of Commerce will provide grants to States to establish and operate offices in China to assist U.S. exporters, with a focus on locations beyond Beijing and Shanghai. The grant amount will not exceed 33% of total costs. Regulations must be promulgated within 270 days. The term "State" and "United States exporter" are defined in the Export Enhancement Act of 1988. $10,000,000 is authorized for the Secretary of Commerce annually from 2008 to 2012 for this section. Amounts appropriated will remain available until expended. SEC. 102. Program to establish China market advocate positions in United States export assistance centers. The Secretary of Commerce will establish a program to assist small- and medium-sized businesses in the US with exporting to China. This program includes creating at least 50 China market advocate positions in US Export Assistance Centers, appointed by the Secretary and trained in trade with China. The program will establish China market advocate positions at US Export Assistance Centers, with advocates receiving training in China's business culture and market. Advocates will be paid based on General Schedule grades and assigned to centers for equitable geographic distribution. China market advocates authorized under subsection (b) shall provide comprehensive assistance to small- and medium-sized businesses in the United States for facilitating exports of goods to China, including finding resources, maintaining contact with businesses in China, resolving disputes, and recruiting. The Secretary of Commerce will advertise services offered by China market advocates to assist US businesses in exporting goods to China. $15,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2008-2012, with $5,000,000 for subsection (b)(2) and $2,000,000 for subsection (d). Assistance to small- and medium-sized businesses for trade missions to China is authorized with $15,000,000 allocated for fiscal years 2008-2012. The Secretary of Commerce will provide assistance to small- and medium-sized businesses in the US for trade missions to China through US Export Assistance Centers. The selection process will focus on the feasibility of exporting goods and services to China, with specific criteria for defining "business-related expenses". Authorization of appropriations is provided. Authorization of Appropriations: $2,000,000 authorized for the Secretary of Commerce annually from 2008 to 2012 for implementing trade mission assistance to small- and medium-sized businesses in the US. SEC. 104. PLAN TO CONSOLIDATE FEES FOR GOLD KEY MATCHING SERVICES IN CHINA. The Secretary of Commerce must submit a plan to Congress to consolidate fees for Gold Key matching services for small- and medium-sized businesses exporting to multiple markets in China. Gold Key matching services include arranging business meetings with contacts in foreign countries. The Secretary of Commerce must submit a plan to Congress to consolidate fees for Gold Key matching services for small- and medium-sized businesses exporting to multiple markets in China. These services include customized market briefings, industry insights, market research, appointments with trade partners, post-meeting debriefings, and assistance with travel logistics. SEC. 201. Trade outreach at the Office of International Trade of the Small Business Administration. The Small Business Act is amended to include provisions for promoting exports to China and establishing a Director of China Program Grants within the Office. The Director must have experience in international trade and government contracts, and will be paid at a rate equal to or greater than a GS-14 level. The Director of China Program Grants will administer grant programs related to Chinese business education under the United States-China Market Engagement and Export Promotion Act. SEC. 202. GRANTS FOR CHINESE BUSINESS EDUCATION PROGRAMS. The Administrator of the Small Business Administration will make grants to institutions of higher education to develop education programs focusing on business in China, including topics like the economy and trade. The Small Business Administration offers grants to institutions of higher education for education programs on China's economy, trade, and export opportunities for US small businesses. Applicants must submit an application to the Director of China Program Grants. Grants are initially for up to 2 years and can be renewed for additional 2-year periods. The Federal share of program costs does not exceed 50 percent. The non-federal share of the cost for education programs on China's economy can be provided in cash or in kind. The term "institution of higher education" is defined as per the Higher Education Act of 1965.
